8/ It's fair to counter that we shouldn't make policy based on China's irrational hurt feelings. Okay, but our China portfolio isn't just Taiwan. It's trade, human rights, NKorea, climate, fentanyl, etc. Shouldn't we consider how Taiwan policy changes affect the whole portfolio?

7/ Further, there's no need for an explicit defense guarantee. China has already priced in a full U.S. defense if they invade, so what do we get by making Taiwan's defense our explicit policy? Again, it's tough talk without enough upside to counter the provocatory downside.

6/ It's a policy that looks strong and tough on China, but does it actually protect our interests? The answer is no. Recognizing Taiwan doesn't actually protect Taiwan; it will just enrage our allies and possibly provoke China into retaliation and a quicker invasion.

5/ But many in Congress and the think tank ecosystem argue that the U.S. must go much further - by ending "strategic ambiguity", recognizing Taiwan, and promising to fully defend Taiwan if China invades. A full reversal of decades of bipartisan consensus on Taiwan policy.

4/ In this context, our Taiwan policy MUST change. We need to expedite and increase arms sales. We should help Taiwan join international bodies. We should sanction Chinese officials who undermine Taiwan. We should fight Chinese anti-Taiwan propaganda.

3/ Our policy is purposely fuzzy. And it has worked.

But now, things are changing. China is getting more aggressive. Undermining and isolating Taiwan. Building up its military. Flexing left and right. Hinting at an invasion in the near future.

2/ For decades, the U.S. has helped secure peace on the island of Taiwan, largely bc of a policy through which we a) neither recognize Taiwan's independence nor recognize China's claim to Taiwan; and b) help Taiwan defend itself without explicitly guaranteeing their security.

7/ Of course there's no way to know for sure whether the new gun law would have prevented this massacre, but the law is kind of tailor made for this scenario. 

The new law gives law enforcement the tools to connect the dots to prevent a shooting like this before it happens.

6/ A red flag order removes guns from the subject and prevents him from buying new guns. It lasts for 6 months and can be renewed.

If a red flag order had been issued in 2020, when Crimo started buying guns, it could have still been in effect today.

5/ The Illinois red flag law allows police to obtain an order (even without the consent of the parents), and with additional funding (also part of the new gun law), it's likely the Highland Park Police would have known that this was a text book case for a red flag order.

4/ But under the new law, each time Crimo bought a gun in 2020, the FBI would have been required to call the Highland Park Police to notify them.

This would have been key information, bc now the Highland Park Police would know that this dangerous kid was stockpiling weapons.

3/ In 2020, Crimo began to buy military style guns. Under current law, the FBI simply checks criminal databases and if there is no arrest (which there wasn't for Crimo), the sale goes through. So the Highland Park police likely didn't know this dangerous kid was buying guns.

2/ The Highland Park killer was known to police. In 2019 police interceded when Crimo tried to kill himself with a machete and again when he threatened to kill family members.

At the time, Crimo didn't own a gun, so a red flag law process wasn't relevant.

The new gun bill requires that local police be notified anytime a 18-20 yr old buys a gun. It also provides funding to help police better administer red flag laws.

These two provisions could have prevented the Highland Park shooting.

10/ Today I’m grieving for all the families who lost loved ones twenty years ago today. And I’m also remembering the day that set in motion the work of millions of Americans chose, in the wake of that terrible day, to try to make their country better and safer.

9/ I was deeply uncomfortable about the way in which America over militarized our response to 9/11. But I didn’t want America to withdraw from the world. So I set about the work of properly learning the lessons of Iraq and Afghanistan, and course correcting U.S. foreign policy.

8/ People always ask me why I spend so much time working on foreign policy and national security issues. 

It all comes back to 9/11. My generation was formed by it. We are defined by it. The choices we have made since then are derivative of it.

7/ But I was a state legislator with no role to play in the biggest issue that affected my generation. I grew frustrated. 

So in early 2005, just over 3 years after 9/11, I decided to make a long shot race for Congress. There I could make a difference I thought.

6/ Within two years America was at war in two far off nations.

I knew Afghanistan was the right war, but as my friends were being sent to fight a war of choice in Iraq, I became more and more worried we had made a costly error as a nation.

5/ The national conversation naturally launched into talk of retribution. 

That night I watched with my parents as Bush declared “We will make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those that harbored them.”

This made perfect sense to me.

4/ I was glued to the TV the rest of the morning, making occasional calls to see if I could connect with friends in the city. 

Eventually I headed to my parents house in Wethersfield where my parents had cable. We would learn that we lost 3 family friends who were in the towers.

3/ As a poor state legislator who spent my entire salary on law school tuition, I didn’t own a proper television or have cable back then. So I pulled out a tiny black and white set and found the antenna only picked up one channel - WTNH.

2/ I was at a meeting at Southington High School, just around the corner from my one bedroom apartment. I watched the initial reports of a plane crash on the small televisions in the school’s library. It looked like an accident at first, and I headed back home.
